journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Educational and Behavioral Statistics

title-group.article-title: Power Analysis for Trials With Discrete-Time Survival Endpoints

bio.title: Authors
bio.p: KATARZYNA JÓŹWIAK is a PhD student at the Methodology and Statistics Department at Utrecht University, The Netherlands. Present address: PoBox 80140, 3508 TC Utrecht, The Netherlands, e-mail: k.jozwiak@uu.nl, tel: +31-(0) 302537983. Her research interests include optimal design of experiments, survival and power analyses.

MIRJAM MOERBEEK, PhD, is an Associate Professor at the Methodology and Statistics Department at Utrecht University, The Netherlands. Present address: PoBox 80140, 3508 TC Utrecht, The Netherlands, e-mail: m.moerbeek@uu.nl, tel: +31-(0) 302531450. Her research interests include optimal design, structural equation modeling and multilevel modeling, power and survival analyses.

abstract.p: Studies on event occurrence aim to investigate if and when subjects experience a particular event. The timing of events may be measured continuously using thin precise units or discretely using time periods. The latter metric of time is often used in social science research and the generalized linear model (GLM) is an appropriate model for data analysis. While the design of trials with continuous-time survival endpoints has been extensively studied, hardly any guidelines are available for trials with discrete-time survival endpoints. This article studies the relationship between sample size and power to detect a treatment effect in a trial with two treatment conditions. The authors use the exponential and the Weibull survival functions to represent constant and varying hazard rates. Furthermore, logit and complementary log–log link functions are used. For constant hazard rates, the power depends on the event proportions at the end of the trial in both treatment arms and on the number of time periods. For varying hazard rates, the power also depends on the shape of the survival functions and different power levels are observed in each time period in case the logit link function is used. For any survival function, power decreases if attrition is present. The authors provide R code to perform the power calculations.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In the fields of social and behavioral science, the occurrence and timing of events is an important issue. A main question is “whether” and “when” subjects experience an observed event and which variables can be used to predict the occurrence and timing of such events. Yoder, Whitbeck, and Hoyt (2001), for example, studied the effects of abuse and neglect on the youths' age at which they first time run away from home. Johnson (2006) examined the time at which students stop out and drop out from university and if different students' characteristics (e.g., gender, family income) affect the risk of departure. Hill, Hawkins, Catalano, Abbott, and Guo (2005) investigated family influences on the onset of young children’s smoking, and Pears, Pierce, Kim, Capaldi, and Owen (2005) considered familial, antisocial behavior, and other factors to study the timing of entry into fatherhood of young, at risk men.

The timing of events can be measured continuously, that is, at a fine-grained time metric. In medical sciences, the primary event is death, which is usually observed in days. For such studies, continuous-time survival analysis can be used, where the most popular model is the Cox (1972) model. However, in the social and behavioral sciences, any event may be studied, and in these fields of science, terms like event history analysis and studies on event occurrence are often used as synonyms of the term survival analysis. In these fields of science, observations are often recorded at intervals (age of having first child) or at discrete points in time (passing examination at the end of the semester), due to practical, financial, or ethical reasons. For instance, in retrospective studies, participants may not remember the exact date of the occurrence of the event. In prospective studies, the budget spared for a trial is restricted to measure the participants too frequently, thereby limiting the number of intervals. To analyze such data, discrete-time survival analysis is used where the generalized linear model (GLM) is the most commonly used model and the data can be easily analyzed with standard software. This model is applied in cases where for each person the data are available for each interval, until and including the interval in which they either experience the event or leave the study for other reasons (i.e., attrition). Discrete-time survival analysis using the GLM is very well presented by Singer and Willett (1993, 2003). Masyn (2003) used a latent variable framework that gives the same parameter estimates as the approach by Singer and Willett (2003). The advantage of Masyn’s approach is that it can be extended to more complicated models, for instance, latent class models to deal with unobserved heterogeneity (Muthén & Masyn, 2005).

The previously mentioned examples focus on observational studies, but of course survival data can also be encountered in experiments. The aim of experiments is to compare one or more new treatments to a control. Masyn (2003), for instance, presented the study of the behavior couples therapy, its effectiveness on the consumption of alcohol by the male partner, and the relationship between drinking and domestic violence. Men who were alcohol abusers entered the study, and they were assigned to one of the three treatment groups: marital treatment, individual-based treatment with no spouse participation, and control treatment without any couples treatment. Subjects were observed for 1 year over periods of 3 months. Ellickson, Bell, and McGuigan (1993) examined the effectiveness of the drug use prevention programs for young adolescents. There were two treatment groups and one control group. Schools in the first treatment group organized lessons for children taught by adult health educators while in the second group, the adult teachers were assisted by older teens. Schools from the control group did not receive that project curriculum. Students had eight lessons in Grade 7 and three lessons in Grade 8, and they filled out questionnaires about their drug use and related attitudes and behavior before and after Grade 7, before and after Grade 8, and once in Grades 9, 10, and 12.

If an effect of the treatment exists in an experiment, researchers would like to detect it with sufficient probability. This probability depends on the size of the effect and on the number of participants. If there is an insufficient number of persons in the study, then the effect may not be found. On the other hand, if the sample size is too large, it may be a waste of time and resources of both the researchers and the participants. Therefore, it is very important to perform the power calculations of the trial to achieve an approximation of the required sample size.

The power and sample size calculations with continuous-time survival endpoints have been already studied in the seventies (George & Desu, 1974; Lee, Desu, & Gehan, 1975), and since then, many articles and books have been published in this field. The power and sample size calculations for survival studies are very well described in the following books: Collet (2003); Machin, Cheung, and Parmar (2006); Chow, Shao, and Wang (2008); Hosmer, Lemeshow, and May (2008); and Julious (2010). There is also software available like nQuery Advisor 7.0 (Elashoff, 2007), PASS (Hintze, 2008), or Study Size (CreoStat, n.d.), which easily performs these calculations.

However, the design of the study for discrete-time survival data is more complex than for continuous time. For such studies, the required number of subjects may very well depend on the number of intervals. So far, there has not been much done to find the power level in studies where events are recorded discretely. Therefore, the aim of this article is to derive the number of subjects in the study on event occurrence where the appropriate event is measured discretely and we take into consideration few time periods. We focus on trials with two treatment conditions and an equal number of participants in both groups at the beginning of the study. First, we present the situation with only one time period in the next section and the explicit formula for computing the power is given. Next, the statistical power for studies with more than one time period is derived in Sections 3 and 4. We include also a hypothetical example to illustrate our approach.

sec.title: 2. One Time Period
sec.p:
The outcome variable Y is a dichotomous response, which means that it takes only two values, 1 when the event occurs and 0 when it does not occur. The same number of subjects are randomly assigned to each of the treatment groups, and we assume that there is no observed heterogeneity between them. The power calculation for one time period that we present in this section and the usual power calculation for a two-group comparison of a binary response without assuming an underlying survival model give similar results. The approach in this section is based on an asymptotic approximation for large samples. For small sample sizes, power calculations should be based on procedures for exact tests (Chow et al. 2008, chap. 5).

sec.title: 3. Multiple Periods With Constant Survival
sec.p: In this and the next section, the power for trials with multiple time periods is studied, where the underlying process is continuous, but recorded discretely. For instance, in the example about the couples therapy, alcohol abusers were observed for 1 year with periods of 3 months. The measurements were taken each 3 months, but the domestic violence could occur at any time during these periods.

In this part of the article, we investigate the effect of the number of time periods, sample sizes and the survival distribution on the statistical power. First we take into consideration the hazard rate that is constant across time and in Section 4 we take into account nonconstant hazard. The first part of both sections studies power for trials without attrition and the effect of attrition on power is taken into account at the end of both sections.

In social and behavior sciences, many events are studied in discrete time, when an interval of time is considered. We assume that subjects enter the study at the same time point, like for instance, in studying grades of first heterosexual intercourse for boys. Each subject also can enter the trial randomly, like in a trial where development of babies in age 0 to 4 months is observed. In either case, the maximal length of time they stay in the trial is the same for all subjects. We also assume that each treatment group has the same number of subjects at the beginning of the study.

The hazard
( h (
t
i k
) )
of subject i in a given period k depends on the underlying continuous-time survival function and the number of time periods. Therefore, to model the risk of the event occurrence in the time intervals the continuous survival function is used. The probability that a person stays in the study up to time t is given by the survival function
S ( t ) = P ( T ≥ t )
with T a continuous random variable for time.

Different survival distributions can be applied in a study of event occurrence. In this section, we use the continuous exponential distribution, which gives
S ( t ) =
e
− λ t
and a constant hazard rate
h ( t ) =
λ
. Time is rescaled to be between 0 and 1, where 0 is the beginning of the study and 1 relates to the end of the study, while t refers to the proportion of time that has elapsed in the study. The parameter
λ
is replaced by
−
l o g
( 1 −
ω
)

∈ [ 0 , 1 ]
denotes the proportion of subjects who have experienced the event at
t = 1

ω
) t
and presented in Figure 1 for different values of
ω

Studying event occurrence in discrete time, we observe that the hazard probabilities, the number of observations and the treatment effect change if we change the number of time intervals as is shown in Table 1. The number of observations increases if the number of time periods increases and larger number of observations results in larger power. The hazard probabilities
h E
and
h C
decrease if the number of periods increases. In the previous section, we already observed that the power level depends on
V a r (
β ˆ
)
, which in its turn depends on the hazard probabilities. Using the clog–log link function, the difference between treatment groups is the same for each number of time periods, but for the logistic link function, the effect of treatment decreases when we take more time periods and smaller effects are related to lower power. Therefore, the probability of detecting the difference between control and experimental conditions depends on the number of time periods through the number of observations, the treatment effect and the hazard probabilities in both groups. We now study the effect of sample size on statistical power level if we combine these three effects together. Unfortunately, we cannot do this on basis of analytical expressions as we did in the previous section for trials with one time period since application of Equation 5 results in formula that are too complicated for any practical use. As an alternative, we study the relation between sample size and power graphically. We do so for three different event proportions in the experimental condition:
ω
E
= .2
,
ω
E
= .5
, and
ω
E
= .8
. For each proportion, we study small (
ω E
−
ω C
= .05
), medium (
ω E
−
ω C
= .10
), and large (
ω E
−
ω C
= .15
) differences between both treatment groups. This gives us nine combinations that are shown in Figure 1. The solid lines represent the survival function in the experimental group, while the dashed lines those in the control group.

caption.p: The Effect of the Number of Time Periods on the Number of Observations, Hazard Probabilities for Control and Experimental Conditions and the Effect of the Treatment, for Exponential Survival Distribution

fn.p: Note. The number of subjects at the beginning of the trial is equal to 1,000.

sec.p:
The power level is presented in Figure 2 for 1, 2, 4, and 8 time periods with event proportions
ω
C
= .35
,
ω
E
= .5
in part (a) and
ω
C
= .65
,
ω
E
= .8
in part (b). These results are given for the logistic model, but the differences in power levels between the logit and clog–log links are usually less than .001.

caption.p: Power levels for exponential survival distribution with logit link function in the model.

sec.p:
We observe that when the event proportions are
ω
C
= .35
and
ω
E
= .5
, the power changes negligibly if the number of time periods increases. However, if these proportions are higher (i.e.,
ω
C
= .65
,
ω
E
= .8
), the power increases only if the number of time periods changes from 1 to 2 and the maximum difference is around 5
%
. There are no big differences in power if the subjects are observed in 2, 4, or 8 time intervals. The maximum difference in power in cases when the subjects are observed in 2 and 4 time intervals is around 1
%
. We also notice that when the event proportions for experimental conditions are close to .5, the power is lower than in the case with larger proportions and consequently the required sample size for the first case is bigger. For instance, the required number of observations to achieve
80 %
power for the case where
ω
C
= .35
,
ω
E
= .5
is equal to 344, while for a study with
ω
C
= .65
,
ω
E
= .8
it is equal to 282.

All the other seven combinations that we have considered give similar results to those presented in Figure 2. The power changes if the number of time intervals changes from 1 to 2 only if
ω
E
= .8
, while it does not increase much if
ω
E
= .5
or
ω
E
= .2
. Furthermore, we observe that the required sample size is smaller for larger differences between the experimental and the control conditions. The power levels in Figure 2 were calculated on basis of the t test, which uses the asymptotic covariance matrix (Equation 5). We also performed a simulation study to obtain power levels and these were almost similar to those obtained in Figure 2.

It should be mentioned that the power levels that are presented in Figure 2 are calculated for trials where subjects only leave the study if they experience the event and not for other reasons. However, in longitudinal studies it is likely that participants drop out for varying reasons; for instance, they get lost to follow-up or refuse to participate any longer. This kind of dropout is called attrition, and since attrition results in a lower sample size it will result in a lower power level. We define the attrition rate as the proportion of subjects that leave during the course of the study due to other reasons than event occurrence. As in the study by Hedeker, Gibbons, and Waternaux (1999), we assume constant dropout over time.

We study now how the power level changes when the attrition rate r or the number of periods changes. We take all nine considered combinations of the event proportions into account and we observe that the power behaves in a similar way in all these cases. As an example, we present in Figure 3 the power for studies with
ω
C
= .35
,
ω
E
= .5
and 2 or 8 time intervals. We notice that power slightly decreases if the attrition rate increases, and the decrease is somewhat larger for eight periods. We need a larger sample size to achieve a desired power when attrition increases. For instance, to achieve the power of .8 in studies with eight periods, the required sample size is 340 if
r = 0
, 354 if
r = .1
, or 436 if
r = .5
. Figure 3.
Power levels for exponential survival distribution with logit link function in the model, ωC = .35, ωE = .5 and different values of attrition rate.

sec.title: 4. Multiple Periods With Nonconstant Survival
sec.p: In this section, we present the power calculations when the trial has multiple time periods and the probability of experiencing the event varies over time. As in the previous section, the underlying process is continuous, but events are recorded in discrete-time intervals. Each of the events can occur at any time during the period, but it is recorded at the end of the interval.

We investigate the case where the hazard
h (
t
i k
)
in a given time period
k
follows from the continuous Weibull distribution. The survival function is given by
S ( t ) =
e
− λ
t τ
and the corresponding hazard rate is represented as
h ( t ) = λ τ
t
τ − 1
, where the parameter
τ ∈ [ 0 , + ∞ )
determines the shape of the survival function. Time is rescaled, such that the smallest value 0 is the beginning of the trial and the highest value 1 denotes the end of the trial. The parameter
λ
is replaced by
−
l o g
( 1 −
ω
)
with
ω
∈ [ 0 , 1 ]
as the proportion of subjects who have experienced the event at time
t = 1
. Given this reparametrization, the survival function is represented as
S ( t ) = ( 1 −
ω
)
t
τ
. Figure 4 shows this function for different values of

and for
τ
= 2
(part (a) of the figure) and

/
2
(part (b) of the figure). The solid lines correspond to the survival for the experimental group and the dashed lines to those in the control group. For
τ
> 1
, the risk of experiencing the event is highest toward the end of the study, so at the beginning of the trial there are still many subjects who have not experienced the event. On the other hand, for
τ
< 1
the risk of experiencing the event is highest toward the beginning of the study, so many events have occurred at the beginning. For
γ
= 1
, the Weibull and exponential functions are the same.
Figure 4.
Weibull survival for different values of the proportion ω and τ = 2 or τ = 1/2.

The general model for discrete-time survival data with clog–log link function is the same as in the previous section given by Equation 3, where the effect treatment does not vary over the time periods.

The discrete-time hazard probability for time period
k

The number of observations increases if the number of time periods increases and it takes higher values if the shape parameter for the Weibull distribution is greater than 1, because in that case the probability of event occurrence is larger toward the end of the trial. We also observe that for any number of time periods

caption.p: The Effect of the Number of Time Periods on the Total Number of Observations, Hazard Probabilities for Control and Experimental Conditions and the Effect of the Treatment, for Weibull Survival Distribution

fn.p: Note. The number of subjects at the beginning of the trial is equal to 1,000.

caption.p: The Effect of the Number of Time Periods on the Total Number of Observations, Hazard Probabilities for Control and Experimental Conditions and the Effect of the Treatment, for Weibull Survival Distribution

fn.p: Note. The number of subjects at the beginning of the trial is equal to 1,000.

sec.p:
From the previous section, we know that the power level depends on the number of time periods through the number of observations, the treatment effect, and the hazard probabilities in both groups. However, now we observe that it also depends on the shape parameter
τ
if the risk of the event occurrence is modeled by the continuous Weibull distribution. We now investigate the power level if all these effects are combined together, and because each time period has its own treatment effect if the logistic link function is used, we have different statistical power in each of these periods. We present first the power for trials where subjects leave the study only when they have experienced the event, and at the end of this section we show how it changes when attrition is taken into account.

As in the previous section, we present the relation between sample size and power level graphically, because the analytical formulation is too complicated. We take into consideration two different values of
τ
:
τ
= 2
and
τ
= 1
/
2
and three values of
ω
for the experimental condition:
ω
E
= .2
,
ω
E
= .5
, and
ω
E
= .8
. We study small (
ω E
−
ω C
= .05
), medium (
ω E
−
ω C
= 0.10
), and large (
ω E
−
ω C
= .15
) effects of the treatment group for each event proportion
ω
E
, and all possible combinations are presented in Figure 4, where the solid lines correspond to the experimental and the dashed lines to the control condition.

For the logit link, the power level for 2 and 4 time periods with event proportions
ω
C
= .65
,
ω
E
= .8
, and
ω
C
= .35
,
ω
E
= .5
and for
τ
= 2
,
τ
= 1
/
2
in Equation 6, is shown in Figures 5 and 6. We observe that the power takes different values if the number of time periods changes and that it differs over the time periods for a given number of time periods. We observe that if
τ
> 1
(left-hand side of the figures), the power takes the smallest value in the first time period while if
τ
< 1
(right-hand side of the figures), the power takes the highest value at the beginning of the study.

caption.p: Power levels for survival Weibull distribution with logit link function in the model and two periods.
Power levels for survival Weibull distribution with logit link function in the model and four periods.

sec.p:
For two time intervals, the difference between power in the first and the second period for the same number of subjects is smaller for
τ
> 1
than for
τ
< 1
, see Figure 5. For four time intervals, the difference in power between periods 1 and 2 is higher than between periods 2 and 3, see Figure 6. Moreover, the difference in power between periods 2 and 3 is usually higher than between periods 3 and 4, but in the case where
ω
C
= .65
,
ω
E
= .8
and
τ
= 2
, the power takes similar values in periods 2 and 4 (so the difference is similar, too).

Tables 4 and 5 present the required number of observations to reach the power level of 0.8. We observe that trials with proportions
ω
C
= .65
and
ω
E
= .8
need fewer subjects than do trials with
ω
C
= .35
and
ω
E
= .5
. Furthermore, the fewer the number of time intervals, the lower the required number of subjects.

caption.p: The Number of Observations Needed to Reach the Power of .8, for the Trial With Two Periods Where Weibull Survival Distribution is Applied
The Number of Observations Needed to Reach the Power of .8, for the trial with Four Periods Where Weibull Survival Distribution is Applied

sec.p:
We have presented our results for a large effect between both treatment groups and the required sample size in that case is much smaller than for medium or small effects. For instance, to reach the power of .8 at the first time interval when
τ
= 1
/
2
and
ω
C
= .4
,
ω
E
= .5
for two time periods, the number of 1,004 observations is required while for
ω
C
= .7
,
ω
E
= .8
, 654 subjects are needed. Therefore, about twice as many subjects should be in the study, if the difference
ω E
−
ω C
is equal to .1 than when it is equal to .15. When
τ
= 2
, the treatment effect is small or there are more time intervals, then the required number of observations is even higher.

If the clog–log link function is used in the general model, then the power level does not vary over the time periods, and it does not depend on the parameter
τ
. Moreover, it takes similar values to the power levels presented in the previous section, when the exponential distribution is used.
As in the previous section, power levels on basis of a simulation study were very similar to those on basis of the t test as presented in Figures 5 and 6.

Figures 5 and 6 assume attrition does not occur. Figure 7 shows the effect of attrition on power for a study where
τ
= 1
/
2
,
ω
C
= .35
,
ω
E
= .5
and there are two or four time intervals. In this figure attrition is defined as in Section 3. It is observed that the power in the first period does not depend on the attrition rate, but it decreases in the subsequent intervals if the attrition rate increases and in each following period this decline is larger. These findings also hold for
τ
= 2
(figure not shown). Figure 7.
Power levels for survival Weibull distribution with logit link function in the model, τ = 1/2, ωC = .35, ωE = .5, and different values of attrition rate.

sec.title: 5. An Example: Drug Use and Property Crime
sec.p: Nowadays, drug usage and property crime are serious problems and there is a widespread belief that addiction to illegal drugs is the cause of the property crime, because drug users might commit crime to get money for their habit. This drug–crime link is of great interest to policymakers and researchers who think that drug intervention programs might reduce social and economic costs of crime. For example, Payne (2006) examined the relationship between drug use initiation and criminal escalation.

To illustrate the results presented in our previous sections, we assume that there are two treatment groups: a control group and a drug intervention program group (methadone program). We believe that the treatment reduces drug addiction and that it helps reducing property crime.

At the beginning of the study, there are 400 persons and they are followed-up for 4 years. We presume that the proportions of persons who have not committed crime during the study are
ω
C
= .65
and
ω
E
= .8
for the control and treatment groups, respectively. Our main question now is how often we should observe the offenders within these 4 years.

Table 6 shows the statistical power for trials where the measurements are taken once each 4 years (1 time period), once each 2 years (2 time periods), or once each year (4 time periods). The results are given for the exponential or the Weibull survival with two different values of the parameter τ (τ is equal to 2 or 1/2). It is observed that for the exponential survival, the power slightly increases with the increasing number of time periods and for any number of time periods, power is equal across time periods. However, for the Weibull survival, the power decreases with increasing number of time periods and given the number of time periods, it changes across time periods. Moreover, when the trial with one time period is conducted, then the power for the Weibull survival is the largest and it takes the same value as for the exponential survival. Therefore, to detect the difference between the control and treatment groups with highest probability, we should follow up offenders for just one period. This is the optimal strategy from a statistical point of view. However, it might be useful to observe offenders more often to be able to sooner take some action when they commit a crime. Then more participants should be recruited at the beginning of the study to have a sufficient power in each of the time periods in case the Weibull survival function is used.

caption.p: Power Levels for the Drug Use and Property Crime Study With N = 400, ωC=.65,andωE=.8

sec.title: 6. Conclusions and Discussion
sec.p: This article presents power calculations for the exponential distribution with constant hazard and a Weibull distribution with varying hazard in each period. For both these cases, we use two different link functions: a logistic and a complementary log–log. We perform all the calculations using R software and our code is available from the first author. To be able to use this software, one must know the survival distribution in advance. As this is often not known at the design phase of the study, researchers can look for information in the literature or believe in their own experience and expectations of the investigation.

Analyzing our results, we observe that power depends on the total number of subjects in both groups and on the proportion of persons who have experienced the event at the end of the study. The power increases if the number of observations increases or the event proportions near the value 0 or 1. In other words, the power to detect a difference between two proportions is not a simple function of the magnitude of the difference but depends upon where along the scale between 0 and 1 the two proportions occur. This was already discussed for a two-group comparison of a binary response (Cohen, 1988, section 6.2), and from our results it also applies to a two-group comparison of discrete-time survival endpoints. The difference in event proportions between both treatment groups is also important. If the difference is larger, the power is also larger and the required number of observations is smaller.

The number of time intervals has an impact on power, but if the exponential survival is applied, power changes only when the number of periods changes from 1 to 2 and only when event proportions are closer to 1, the difference in power is relevant.

In our study, the power for exponential survival with logistic or clog–log link functions and for Weibull survival with clog–log takes similar values for the same number of subjects. Exclusively, for Weibull survival with logistic link function, we get different results. In that case, the statistical power takes different values in each time period for a given number of time intervals and higher values are observed if the number of time intervals decreases. For instance, the power levels are higher for two than for four time periods. Therefore, the required sample size is smaller if the number of time periods decreases. Additionally, the power depends on the shape parameter τ. For
τ
> 1
, the power takes the smallest value in the first time period and then increases, while for
τ
< 1
, the power takes the highest value at the beginning of the study and then decreases.

Moerbeek (2008) investigated the power for longitudinal intervention studies with two treatment groups, where the outcomes are continuous and the author observed that the statistical power increases if the number of measurements increases from 2 to 3. If there are more than three measurements, the difference in power is negligible. Raudenbush and Liu (2001) analyzed the effect of study duration, frequency of observations, and sample size on power in studies of group differences. They also noticed that increasing the sample size generally has a greater effect on power than increasing number of time points.

We can conclude now that, from a statistical point of view, it is better to recruit a large number of participants in the trial and observe them infrequently, for example, two or three times during the study. However, this is not always a good strategy in practice. For instance, in an experiment where delinquent youth are given a psychosocial treatment, researchers would like to observe them rather frequently to ascertain early whether they relapse to criminal life or not and to be able to use appropriate means of punishment once relapse occurs.

Our results are based on assumptions such as an equal sample size in both groups and the same maximum length of time for each participant. In our future research, we aim to modify these assumptions. We will try to find an optimal duration, sample size in both treatment groups and location of the measurements points using optimality criteria. In Berger and Wong (2009), authors recommend using equal sample sizes for both groups in a case where the logistic model with one dichotomous independent variable is used. However, in our work we consider trials with multiple time periods and both groups have the same number of participants only at the beginning of the study. Therefore, the unequal sample sizes design might be a better strategy in such trials. Duration of the trial is also a very important issue, because if it is too short, then many subjects may not experience the event by the end of the study. On the other hand, if the duration is too long, then persons may not be willing to participate in a trial. Therefore, we aim to find a suitable duration of the trial in our future research. We will also take into consideration the costs of the study. It is important to understand how to design the trial, such that the budget is optimally used, because costs are involved when participants are recruited and measured. The treatment cost should also be taken into account, because it might be different over the treatment conditions. Therefore, the optimal number of subjects and measurements such that a sufficient power level is achieved at a minimal cost is an issue which we will study in our future work.

To our knowledge, this is the first article that presents power calculation for trials with discrete-time survival endpoints. The results mights be very useful to researchers in the field of social and behavioral science.
